title: National Black History Month, 2026
summary: Proclamation 11008 of February 3, 2026, declares February 2026 as National Black History Month, coinciding with the 250th anniversary of American independence. The proclamation emphasizes that Black history is an integral part of American history, highlighting the timeless contributions of Black Americans to the nation's government, laws, military, economy, workforce, and culture. It asserts that the strength of the nation lies in a shared commitment to freedom, not differences, and criticizes attempts to divide citizens based on race. The document celebrates Black American heroes like Prince Estabrook, Lemuel Haynes, Phillis Wheatley, Harriet Tubman, Frederick Douglass, Jesse Owens, Katherine Johnson, and Thomas Sowell for their roles in defending American values and liberty. It also mentions the planned National Garden of American Heroes honoring Black icons, an Executive Order to promote excellence at Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and ongoing efforts to improve safety, affordability, and the American Dream for all. The proclamation calls for public officials and citizens to observe the month with appropriate programs and activities.
